alternatives.transcript: sweetie a 26 public television for greater Washington good evening in the news this Friday the Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted for sanctions against South Africa a former prosecutor challenged William rehnquist testimony denying voter intimidation the unemployment rate fell to six point nine percent in June the freed hostages

father Jenco arrived back in the u.s. to a greeting from President Reagan and a huge welcome in Chicago we'll have the details of these stories in our news summary coming up Judy Woodruff has in Washington tonight Judy after the news summary we start with an extended look at the final day of Senate Judiciary Committee hearings on the nomination of William rehnquist then we analyze Congressional maneuvering over sanctions against South Africa next a report and a discussion on changing work rules in Big Industry and the implications for
I'm labor and management finally excerpts from hearings on Capitol Hill over whether cigarette ads should be completely banned

the battle over Banning tobacco ads resumed on Capitol Hill today it was the second of two days of Congressional hearings on the proposal two weeks ago at the first hearing anti-tobacco forces brought out a star-studded cast to support the smoking ban including the daughter of the late actor Yul Brynner who died of lung cancer and a young man many would have expected on the

other side of the issue Patrick Reynolds grandson of the founder of the RJ Reynolds tobacco company I was a boy my father Richard J Reynolds jr. died at age 58 from emphysema caused by his heavy smoking

it hurt terribly as a youngster watching my father slowly die from an extremely debilitating and chronic disease caused by his heavy cigarette smoking when my grandfather began manufacturing cigarettes of the turn of the century he did not know that smoking causes emphysema heart disease and cancer now that this has been absolutely proven it is important to me to speak out

figure it out over time seeing is the single biggest lie perpetrated on the American people I believe that cigarette advertising is promotion of a poisonous product and that it is moral right and goods eliminate all advertising of cigarettes this is a virtually black-and-white question to allow continued advertising of cigarettes when they are proven Killers is plainly immoral

I do not know whether to laugh or to cry when I read newspapers articles in which representatives of tobacco Industries are quoted as saying that the money spent on advertisement and promotion is simply done to get present users to switch to a particular brand mr. chairman it is obvious that this industry must constantly try to get new smokers to replace the ones who have quit or who have died

my father was not the type of person who tried to sell others his ideas of morality he respected the right of the individual to live by his own standards however after his experience with cancer his concern about the deadly effects of smoking led him to speak out

Yul Brynner's dead and I think by now you all know why I don't want to forget his suffering and the bad experience after my father died our family authorize the production of an advertisement in the nonprofit world it is called a public service announcement it is an ant that the tobacco companies would pay dearly not to have shown on television and I would like to share it with you now
I really wanted to make a commercial when I discovered that I was that sick and my time was so limited on the make up commercial that says simply now that I'm gone I tell you don't smoke
whatever you do just don't smoke

at today's hearing the tobacco industry and its supporters got a chance to give their side of the story fundamental principle that undergirds the First Amendment and the values that have kept the First Amendment strong is that when you regulate people's lives you do so openly if you wish to regulate smoking in the United States do so open but don't engage in covert regulation through the manipulation of information that is the indicia of every society in this world

but we fight that we think that we have we have the we have adopted an open Society a society in which free trade and ideas and free trade and information is what is what makes the society go it is based on a premise that individuals Americans are capable of making rational autonomous judgments advertising is not the all powerful force that has been alleged in earlier testimony those who favor Banning restricting advertising vastly

estimate the power of advertising and underestimate the intelligence and will of consumers Decades of ever ties in research clearly demonstrates the consumers are not Pavlov's dogs malleable putty or blank slates individual audience members bring to advertisements they see the sum of myriad experiences and beliefs and they evaluate commercial messages not in a vacuum but in the context of their lives my own research has shown that when people are exposed to advertising they may ignore it go to the bathroom laughs forget or even counter argue

for example you might disregard the most appealing advertisement for a fast food chain because you're on a diet or you don't like what you regard to be junk food or you may decide against chewing gum despite the beautiful people in the gum commercials because you think the chewing gum is unattractive cigarette advertising even contains the counter argument in the surgeon general's warnings in each and every ad speaking now not as on the legal issue but as a representative of the administration I think the Administration has very serious concerns about this legislation

we're not talking about illicit drugs here where clearly Congress has a mandate a strong mandate not only to ban a hits advertising but the bandits use and consumption we're talking about a product that is lawful and given that I think the administration is of the belief that we would much prefer to come down on the side of a free and open society and Trust American people to make the correct decision
the Congress will not complete its consideration of the cigarette advertising ban this session final action on any bill is expected to come next year
